Details: Two distinct approaches to SQL Server to PySpark migration cost estimation. Agent 1 provides comprehensive enterprise-level analysis with detailed cost breakdowns and extensive effort estimates (216-280 hours). Agent 2 offers conservative estimates with simplified calculations (30 hours total). Significant variance in both cost projections and implementation effort estimates.

Both outputs address SQL Server to PySpark migration cost estimation with similar core objectives. Agent 1 focuses on enterprise-scale implementation with detailed operational costs, while Agent 2 provides conservative estimates for smaller-scale deployment. Both cover runtime costs and implementation effort but with vastly different scales and assumptions.

Both outputs follow similar structural organization: Cost Estimation section followed by Code Fixing/Testing Effort section. Agent 1 uses hierarchical numbering (1.1, 2.1) and includes optimization opportunities, while Agent 2 uses simpler structure with summary table. Both conclude with API costs and assumptions.

Mathematically sound calculations with proper cost breakdowns. Minor formatting inconsistencies in some bullet points. All numerical calculations verify correctly (daily $13.66 × 30 = $409.80, monthly × 12 = $4,985.90). Effort estimates well-structured across development and testing phases.

Conservative but mathematically correct estimates. DBU calculations properly structured (4 nodes × 2 hours × 1 DBU = 8 DBU). Cost range calculations accurate ($0.15-$0.75 × 8 DBU). Summary table formatting could be improved for better readability.

Both outputs demonstrate strong syntactic correctness with proper numerical calculations and logical flow. Agent 1 shows more comprehensive analysis depth while Agent 2 provides clearer conservative estimates.

Excellent comprehensive analysis suitable for enterprise-level planning. Consider adding conservative scenario estimates for comparison. Strengthen assumptions documentation and add risk mitigation strategies.

Good conservative approach ideal for initial planning phases. Consider expanding cost analysis to include multiple scenarios (low/medium/high complexity). Add more detailed breakdown of testing phases and potential optimization strategies.
